sentences: Christopher Cross (born Christopher Charles Geppert; May 3, 1951) is an American singer, songwriter, musician, and composer from San Antonio, Texas.
Cross won five Grammy Awards for his eponymous debut album released in 1979.
The singles "Sailing" (1980), and "Arthur's Theme (Best That You Can Do)" (from the 1981 film Arthur) peaked at number one on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100.
The singles "Sailing" (1980), and "Arthur's Theme (Best That You Can Do)" (from the 1981 film Arthur) peaked at number one on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100.
"Sailing" earned three Grammys in 1981, while "Arthur's Theme" won the Oscar for Best Original Song in 1981 (with co-composers Burt Bacharach, Carole Bayer Sager, and Peter Allen).
Cross first played with a San Antonio-based cover band named Flash before signing a solo contract with Warner Bros. in 1978.
He also played guitar during a Deep Purple concert in 1970 when Ritchie Blackmore fell ill shortly before the show.
Cross released his self-titled debut album, Christopher Cross, in 1979.

After 1984, Cross's star quickly dimmed.

sentences: Cross made three more albums in the 1990s, and although some of his releases gained critical response, he was not able to attract the mass audience he once enjoyed.
After his decline in fame in the mid-1980s, he toured and opened for various acts during the 1990s.
The year 2002 saw the release of Very Best of... album, and in 2007 he completed a Christmas album titled A Christopher Cross Christmas.
In 2008, Cross recorded a new acoustic album of his hits titled The Cafe Carlyle Sessions.
In 2011, Cross released a new studio album titled Doctor Faith.
In 2013, he released A Night in Paris, a 2-CD live album he recorded and filmed in April 2012 at the Theatre Le Trianon in Paris, France.

In 2017, he played a concert in his hometown, at the Tobin Center, San Antonio, Texas.
In 2018, he joined with other musicians in Austin to form the band Freedonia.

He attended Alamo Heights High School in San Antonio and graduated in 1969.
Cross was married to Roseanne Harrison from 1973 until the couple divorced in 1982.
Cross was married to Roseanne Harrison from 1973 until the couple divorced in 1982.
His 1988 marriage to Jan Bunch ended in a 2007 divorce.
On April 3, 2020, Cross confirmed through his Facebook page that he had tested positive for the COVID-19 virus, and was ill, but was recovering.
On October 18, 2020, during an interview with CBS Sunday Morning, Cross described what COVID-19 is like for him, in his first public appearance since contracting the virus.
In 2019 he prepared to go on tour in 2020 as a 40th year celebration of his successful debut album bearing his name.
In 2019 he prepared to go on tour in 2020 as a 40th year celebration of his successful debut album bearing his name.
He had dates booked at various venues in the United States beginning in early 2020, but the Covid pandemic rapidly became widespread.
Finally in September 2021 when restrictions were greatly softened, he began fulfilling those concert dates and once again performing live in front of packed venues nationwide.

Cross filled in for guitarist Ritchie Blackmore of Deep Purple (who had fallen ill) by performing with the band in San Antonio, Texas, in 1970.
Cross contributed backing vocals (along with The Beach Boys' Carl Wilson) to David Lee Roth's 1985 hit "California Girls".
Cross performed the song "Sailing" alongside the pop band 'N Sync at the Fifth Annual Blockbuster Entertainment Awards in 1999.

Cross also contributed French horn and bassoon solos on "Two Tickets To Paradise: The Money Vegas Duets" an unreleased album of Eddie Money collaborations with Indie cult hero Greg Vegas of Monsterland, Explodee, and Hat City Intuitive fame in 1995.

sentences: "All Right" was used by CBS Sports for its highlights montage following the 1983 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament, while "Think of Laura" is used as a reference to characters on the soap opera General Hospital.
He also co-wrote and sang the song "A Chance For Heaven" for the 1984 Summer Olympic Games.

Another notable San Antonian, the historian and author Light Townsend Cummins, had grown up in that same house a decade earlier.
Cross performed his hit song "Ride Like the Wind" on the NBC show Late Night with Jimmy Fallon on Monday, October 5, 2009, in a "Yacht Rock" themed episode.
He was joined by Michael McDonald, whom he has worked with in the past.
As the credits were rolling, Cross, McDonald, and The Roots, the Fallon house band, broke into "Sailing", which he also performed in an online-only performance on NBC.com.
